abstract.p: Home Depot co-founder and chmn Bernard Marcus and Georgia Gov Roy E Barnes will travel to Israel in June to encourage Israeli high-technology companies to set up US offices in Georgia; Israeli has second-highest density of high-tech start-ups outside Silicon Valley; Georgia ranked fifth among US states in growth for high-tech jobs from 1993 to 1998 and hopes to market itself as lower-cost alternative to Silicon Valley; photo (M)

block.p: The Silicon Valley of the Deep South? With Israel's help, that is what Bernard Marcus, co-founder and chairman of Home Depot, wants Georgia to become.
A delegation led by Mr. Marcus and Gov. Roy E. Barnes is heading to Jerusalem, Tel Aviv, Haifa and Yoknean next month to persuade Israeli technology companies to make Georgia their American home.
The Silicon Valley of the Deep South? With Israel's help, that is what Bernard Marcus, co-founder and chairman of Home Depot, wants Georgia to become.
A delegation led by Mr. Marcus and Gov. Roy E. Barnes is heading to Jerusalem, Tel Aviv, Haifa and Yoknean next month to persuade Israeli technology companies to make Georgia their American home.
''There are no boundaries any more,'' said Mr. Marcus, whose company is based in Atlanta. ''They have lots of bright people there who are transcending the barriers.''

Israel has the second highest density of high-tech start-ups outside of Silicon Valley, according to the American-Israeli Chamber of Commerce. Among the states, the American Electronics Association ranked Georgia fifth in growth for high-tech jobs from 1993 to 1998.
Mr. Marcus, international chairman of the Israel Democracy Institute, an independent political research organization in Jerusalem, has often visited Israel for both business and pleasure.

With markedly lower costs than Silicon Valley and many other parts of the country, he says, Atlanta is a practical alternative. ''We're building, slowly, a strong infrastructure for information systems in Georgia,'' he said. ''All the things they want, we've got them.''
